subject: [junit] Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial software development ?
msgSnippet: ... Thanks for the reference. Took a quick look. It seems like your basic mvc pattern thing. JUnit is good for model testing. The thing that I don t know is
messageBody:
>Micheal Feather's "The Humble Dialog"?[1].

Thanks for the reference. Took a quick look. It seems like your basic mvc
pattern thing. JUnit is good for model testing. The thing that I don't know
is how to test a complex SWING GUI with all the associated events.

Thanks for the indulgence.
-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of
Mark Levison
Sent: Thursday, February 09, 2006 9:05 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial
software development ?


> >As developers of desktop GUI applications
> >(Swing/Eclipse SWT/WinForms .NET) - its a bit more difficult
> >to test some of our code
>
> I realize that the following question does not belong in the JUnit
mailing
> list. However, request the favor of a quick indulgence. Would you be
> willing
> to share some url's that talk about testing Swing apps ?


Sorry we did that work about 5 years ago now. I expect that most of our
testing was about the business logic. BTW if you're interested in testing
GUI's have your considered Micheal Feather's "The Humble Dialog"?[1].

Cheers
Mark Levison

[1] http://www.objectmentor.com/resources/articles/TheHumbleDialogBox.pdf
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Blog: http://dotnetjunkies.com/WebLog/mlevison/
